channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. & A.: David Der-wei Wang on C.T. Hsia, Chinese Literary Critic
item.description: C.T. Hsia, who died in New York on Dec. 29 aged 92, was a cosmopolitan scholar who established a Chinese literary canon in the West, said his friend and colleague David Der-wei Wang.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: C.T. Hsia, right, with his wife, Della Hsia, and David Der-wei Wang at a restaurant in 2013.

item.title: U.S. Orders Evacuation of Staff From Embassy in South Sudan
item.description: The United States began evacuating American citizens as the fighting spread in December, but the embassy in Juba, the capital, remains open.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Hull Journal: As the Working Poor Become More Common in Britain, So Does Hunger
item.description: Five years of economic weakness, austerity and rising prices have left a mark, with at least 500,000 people in Britain reliant on food aid, three times more than a year ago.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: India Ink: A Hunting Community in Nagaland Takes Steps Toward Conservation
item.description: In 2012, people in the northeastern state killed about 150,000 federally protected Amur falcons. In 2013, the number dropped to zero, after a campaign by the state and nonprofit groups to promote the value of wildlife.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA SINHA

item.title: Cambodian Police Fire on Protesters as Clashes Turn Violent
item.description: Military police officers killed at least three people, officials said, as antigovernment protests against the decades-old rule of Prime Minister Hun Sen entered a volatile new phase.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Attack on Chinese Consulate Puts U.S. on Defensive
item.description: The New Year’s Day arson attack in San Francisco has prompted Chinese media to criticize United States security measures, as American officials have vowed to apprehend those responsible.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: Wang Chuan, spokesman for the Chinese consulate, spoke with reporters in front of the consulate's scorched entrance on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: With Downed Balloon, China and Japan Cooperate
item.description: A Chinese balloonist who attempted to land on a disputed islet in the East China Sea was rescued by the Japanese Coast Guard, a rare peaceful resolution in fiercely contested waters.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:credit: Japan Coast Guard/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The hot-air balloon was spotted in the East China Sea, near islands disputed by China and Japan.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Complex Effort for Antarctic Rescue
item.description: Video and images shared on social media show the long-awaited rescue of the 52 passengers of a Russian ship, the Akademik Shokalskiy, which has been trapped in ice off the coast of Antarctica since Dec. 24.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Hezbollah Moving Long-Range Missiles From Syria to Lebanon, an Analyst Says
item.description: The Shiite militia has been moving long-range missiles to Lebanon from bases inside Syria, according to an Israeli national security analyst, who said the missiles could strike deep inside his country.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: U.S. Military Ship Readied for Mission to Destroy Syria’s Chemical Weapons
item.description: The entire process, which officials said they hoped would begin within the next two weeks, would take roughly 90 days to complete, allowing for weather and other factors.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER
item.media:description: The Cape Ray, part of the maritime reserve fleet in Portsmouth, Va., awaits orders to collect 700 tons of Syria’s lethal chemical weapons and destroy them at sea.

item.title: Banned Substances Claim an Outsize Role in Athletics in India
item.description: Indian athletes, with easy access to legal steroids and minimal support from their nation, lead the world in suspensions for performance-enhancing drug use.
item.dc:creator: By REBECCA BYERLY

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Central African Republic: Violence Forces Aid Group to Curtail Work
item.description: Doctors Without Borders said it had drastically scaled back operations at an airport encampment in Bangui, the capital, because of a growing political and sectarian crisis.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Libya: 2 Foreigners Are Found Dead
item.description: A British man and a New Zealand woman were found shot to death near an oil and gas complex in western Libya, a security official said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Troops Break Up Strike
item.description: Soldiers on Thursday broke up a demonstration by garment factory workers who were striking for better pay, detaining Buddhist monks and labor leaders.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: 233 Migrants Are Rescued at Sea
item.description: The Italian Navy said Thursday that it had rescued 233 migrants from an overcrowded smugglers’ boat in rough seas south of Sicily.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Allowed to Join the Bar, but Not to Take a Job
item.description: A 36-year-old brought to the country from Mexico as a child can be admitted to the state bar, the California Supreme Court said. But, under federal law, no law firm can legally hire him.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER MEDINA
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sergio Garcia, 36, in September at his Durham, Calif., home.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: India: At Least 30 Die in Bus Crash
item.description: A bus plunged 400 feet into a gorge on Thursday in western India after the driver lost control, killing at least 30 people, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Deadly Bombing in Beirut Suburb, a Hezbollah Stronghold, Raises Tensions
item.description: The explosion of a car bomb in a Beirut suburb appeared to be the latest in a string of bombings in Lebanon linked to the civil war in neighboring Syria.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: While Kerry Pushes Peace Talks, Israeli Leader Airs Criticism
item.description: Upon the arrival of Secretary of State John Kerry in Israel, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu questioned the Palestinian commitment to peace.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: From Ore to Nuggets, With Peril
item.description: Indonesian villagers use mercury to process the ore from small-scale mines, work that carries risks to themselves and the environment.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Qaeda-Aligned Militants Threaten Key Iraqi Cities
item.description: Radical Sunni militants freed prisoners, set fire to police stations and seized mosques in Falluja and Ramadi, two of Iraq’s most important cities.
item.dc:creator: By YASIR GHAZI and TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Armed tribesmen and Iraqi police officers stood guard on Thursday as clashes raged in Ramadi, west of Baghdad.

item.title: The Lede: Egyptian Puppet Called Terrorist Mouthpiece
item.description: Egypt’s crackdown on support for the Muslim Brotherhood has turned surreal as prosecutors agreed to investigate the allegation that a puppet in a phone ad was sending coded instructions to Islamist terrorists.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and LIAM STACK

item.title: Books of The Times: ‘Ping-Pong Diplomacy,’ by Nicholas Griffin
item.description: “Ping-Pong Diplomacy” builds up to the events of 1971, when an American team was unexpectedly invited to visit China to participate in a table tennis competition.
item.dc:creator: By JANET MASLIN
item.media:description: Richard Bergmann was a world champion who fought on D-Day. His story is one of many told in "Ping-Pong Diplomacy."

item.title: Dispute Threatens Completion of Panama Canal Expansion
item.description: The builders are warning that their construction work is set to be suspended if the Panama Canal Authority does not agree to pay for the overruns within 21 days, “in line with the contractual terms.”
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Myanmar’s Leader Backs Change to Constitution
item.description: President Thein Sein said he would support changing the Constitution to allow “any citizen” to become president, apparently a reference to Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Prize-winning democracy advocate, during a rally in December.
